msItem.textLang: Primitive Irish written in Ogham script
Latin written in Latin script with Irish personal names

support.p: rejected monument Dyfed Archaeological Trust Historic Environment Record: 3740 Parciau (Parke)
support.note: Spotted dolerite with 5-10 per cent albitized feldspar phenocrysts (1-10mm) (Edwards 2007, 219-220).

supportDesc.condition: A rough, irregular pillar with a rounded top and five faces, the stone is in good condition. Macalister (1945, 348) claims that the stone once bore an ogham inscription which has since been disintegrated and probably hammered or rubbed away with intention. According to Macalister (1945, 348) both the top and bottom of the inscribed angle are spalled, and the inscription is recognisable only by the hollows which the groups of letter-scores have left on the two sides of the angle. Edwards (2007, 219) remarks that the Latin inscription is in good condition except for the last letter of the first line which is partially buried.

layoutDesc.layout: Macalister maintains that in 1922 he saw a line of ogham on the sinister angle of the stone reflecting the Latin inscription. He describes it as at best, for the greater part of its length, it is recognizable only by the hollows which the groups of letter-scores have left on the two sides of the angle (Macalister 1945, 348-349). Edwards (2007, 219) states, however, that there is no corresponding ogham inscription on the stone. The roman-letter inscription begins nearly halfway down the south face of the stone and consists of two lines reading vertically downwards.

handDesc.handNote: Macalister (1945, 348) offered no details about the execution of the ogham inscription, so the carving technique is unknown. However, he did note that the Latin inscription was predominantly chiselled with a few letters pocked (1945, 348), while Edwards (2007, 219) described it as being quite deeply incised. The Latin inscription contains capitals, except for a miniscule Q, which has an open loop (Edwards 2007, 219). The A's have angle-bars and the I's at the ends of both lines are horizontal. In line 2 FI and LI are conjoined and the I's are of small size; the top horizontal of the F slopes upward and the bottom downward; L has a downward sloping horizontal; B has separate loops and R has an extended vertical (Edwards 2007, 219).

origin.origPlace: Henllan Amgoed, Carmarthenshire, Wales 51.845989, -4.650858 National Grid Reference: SN 175 197
origin.origDate: Second half of the sixth century A.D.

history.provenance: The stone was first discovered by Lhuyd, lying on the ground in a field belonging to Parciau. Shortly before 1868 the stone was moved from the field known as Parc-y-Maen ('the Field of the Stone') to its present location, northwest of the farmhouse. Macalister seems to have been the first to suggest that the stone was inscribed with ogham, but McManus dismisses the presence of ogham as 'imaginary'.
Now situated northwest of the farmhouse.

div.p: Edwards (2007, 219) notes that both names in the Latin inscription are Irish and relatively late (post-syncope). QVENVENDANI (genitive) is a later form of the name seen in Ireland in ogham, QENOVENDAGNI (see Macalister 1945, 3-4 CIIC: no 2), which is the ancestor of Irish Cennf(h)innán, 'white-headed one'. The second name, BARCVNI, is a Latinized genitive of the ancestor of the Old Irish name Barrchú, 'dog-head' (although theoretically it could be a British name *Bargwn). (Edwards 2007, 219).
